['Marble - A metamorphic rock commonly quarried for building and sculpting purposes due to its beauty and durability.', 'Granite - An igneous rock frequently used in construction, known for its strength and aesthetic appeal.', 'Limestone - A sedimentary rock widely used in the creation of cement, lime, and as a building material.', 'Slate - A fine-grained metamorphic rock primarily extracted for roofing shingles due to its durability.', 'Sandstone - A clastic sedimentary rock often quarried for use in construction projects such as foundations and decorative stones.', 'Quartzite - An incredibly hard, non-foliated metamorphic rock used in landscaping and building materials due to its resistance to weathering.', 'Basalt - A dark igneous rock typically quarried for road base or as crushed stone aggregate.', 'Schist - A foliated metamorphic rock extracted for ornamental purposes, especially when it contains attractive minerals like mica or garnet.', 'Flint - An organic sedimentary rock used in the past to make flints and arrowheads due to its ability to produce sparks when struck against steel.', 'Chalk - A soft, white, porous form of limestone widely quarried for use in agriculture as a soil amendment or construction aggregate.', 'Travertine - A form of limestone deposited by mineral springs, often quarried for its unique textures and colors used in building facades and decorative elements.', 'Slate - Another type of slate, specifically extracted from metamorphic rocks for use as roofing material due to its flat layers and waterproof properties.', 'Gneiss - A high-grade metamorphic rock with a banded appearance quarried occasionally for ornamental purposes.', 'Phyllite - A low-grade metamorphic rock similar in texture to slate, often extracted for use as building stone or decorative elements.', 'Shale - A fine-grained sedimentary rock that splits into thin layers and quarried primarily for fuel (as coal) but also used in the production of bricks, tiles, and other construction materials.', 'Onyx - A metamorphic rock composed mainly of calcite or aragonite formed through hydrothermal processes; it is often cut into decorative slabs and used for ornamental purposes.', "Quartz monzonite - An igneous rock that's similar to granite, quarried occasionally due to its durability and appearance but less common in construction than other rocks like granite.", 'Diorite - A coarse-grained intrusive igneous rock composed mainly of plagioclase feldspar and pyroxene; it is sometimes used as dimension stone or for decorative purposes due to its speckled appearance.', 'Marble (different color variety) - Another type of marble quarried in various locations around the world, often distinguished by unique patterns or colors.', "Dolomite rock - A sedimentary carbonate rock that contains significant dolomite mineral content; it's occasionally quarried for use as a construction aggregate due to its hardness and durability."]

['Bolt - A cylindrical metal fastener with a head on one end and a helical ridge (also known as threads) on the other for driving into pre-drilled holes in wood or metal.', 'Screw - An inclined, threaded shaft designed to hold objects together or form an object.', 'Nut - A fastener with a hexagonal hole that fits over the corresponding screw threads and is used to secure two parts together.', 'Rivet - A permanent mechanical fastener consisting of a smooth cylindrical pin, usually metal, with a head on one end.', 'Pin - A small, stiff piece of metal used to join or align separate objects.', 'Key - A piece of metal inserted into a groove around the shaft of a screw or bolt to prevent loosening due to vibration.', 'Lug - A projecting part on an object that is designed to engage with another, usually for fastening purposes.', 'Clevis - A U-shaped piece of metal used in conjunction with a pin for attaching or fixing objects together.', 'Clamp - A device consisting of two parallel jaws joined by a screw or a lever mechanism, designed to hold or clamp materials tightly together.', 'Buckle - A fastener made up of a single piece that can be deformed and then returned to its original shape when released; often used for joining parts of leather goods.', 'Staple - A small strip-shaped nail with two (or sometimes more) sharp points at one end, typically used to fasten pieces of wood or cloth together.', 'Latch - A simple mechanical device that joins two objects but can be easily separated when a specific action is performed.', 'Cam lock - A type of pin-latching system commonly found in furniture and cabinetry; consists of a cam on one side and an attached latch mechanism on the other.', 'Hinge - A pivot device that allows two objects to rotate relative to each other, typically used for doors or gates.', 'Pins - Metal fasteners with tapered ends inserted into pre-drilled holes in wood pieces; not directly joining mechanisms but can secure them together.', 'Dowel - A cylindrical rod made of wood, metal, plastic, or composite material used to align and join multiple parts together.', 'Bracket - A supportive structure with a pair of arms or legs that are used for holding or attaching objects in place; often serves as an anchor point for fasteners.', 'Snap-fit - An assembly technique where two interlocking pieces fit tightly against each other, typically held together by the pressure exerted when one piece is pushed into another.', 'Magnetic clamp - A type of clamp that utilizes magnets to hold objects in place; can be used for temporary or semi-permanent fastening.', 'Adhesive tape - A strip of flexible material with adhesive on one side, designed to stick materials together when pressed against each other; not a mechanical fastener but often used to join parts temporarily or as an alternative solution.']

['Cotton - A natural soft fabric derived from cotton plant fibers, often used in clothing and home textiles.', 'Silk - An exquisite and luxurious soft fabric made from silkworm cocoons, popular for formal wear and high-end bedding.', 'Linen - A semi-synthetic fabric made from flax plant fibers that have a unique combination of softness and durability when treated properly.', 'Cashmere - A fine, soft wool obtained from cashmere goats, known for its superior warmth, softness, and hypoallergenic properties.', 'Flannel - A soft cotton or woolen fabric that has a brushed finish to give it a fuzzy texture.', 'Chambray - A lightweight twilled fabric similar to denim, but made with a lighter colored warp yarn and darker weft yarn for added softness.', 'Jersey - A stretchy knit fabric derived from either cotton or wool, commonly used in athletic wear and casual clothing.', 'Muslin - A lightweight natural cotton fabric with a plain weave, known for its breathability and versatility.', 'Velour - An upholstery fabric made from polyester fibers that have been given a soft pile finish, often used in furniture and sportswear.', 'Suede - A type of leather with a napped surface, created by sanding or using special machinery to give it a soft texture.', 'Microfiber - Ultra-soft synthetic fabric made from extremely fine fibers that are used for cleaning and upholstery due to its ability to capture dust and moisture.', 'Seersucker - A lightweight, crinkled cotton fabric with a puckered appearance, typically in pastel colors, often worn in warm weather.', 'Tencel - A sustainable and soft fabric made from wood pulp using an environmentally friendly process, known for its breathability and moisture-wicking properties.', 'Hemp - A natural fiber obtained from the hemp plant, which has become increasingly popular due to its durability and moderately soft texture.', 'Blended Fabric - A fabric made by combining two or more different types of fibers, such as cotton with polyester or wool with nylon, resulting in a softer feel.', 'Knitted Clothing - Any clothing item that has been knitted using soft yarns and stitch patterns to create comfortable fabrics like t-shirts, sweaters, and hats.', 'Organic Fabric - A fabric made from organically grown fibers without the use of pesticides or synthetic chemicals, known for its natural softness and breathability.', 'Throw Pillow Cover - A decorative pillow cover typically filled with a soft material like cotton batting or polyester fiberfill, providing comfort and plushness to living spaces.', 'Softener Sheet - An additive sheet used in the laundry process that is placed between clothing items during washing and drying to enhance fabric softness by coating fibers with a lubricant-like substance.', 'Bamboo Fabric - A sustainable and naturally antibacterial soft fabric made from bamboo plant fibers, often used in eco-friendly clothing or bedding items.', "Jersey Knit - A lightweight knitted fabric commonly associated with T-shirts, characterized by its stretchy properties due to the jersey weave's interlocking loops."]

['Musician - A person who plays an accordion or other musical instruments professionally.', 'Folk music - Traditional and cultural music genre often performed with the accordion as one of its main instruments.', 'Polka - A lively folk dance originating in Central Europe, commonly accompanied by accordions.', 'Zydeco - A genre of French Creole music from Louisiana, frequently featuring accordion-led rhythms and melodies.', 'Bagpipes - Although not directly related to the accordion, bagpipes share a similar compact design and function as wind instruments.', 'Reed instrument - Accordions are reed instruments that produce sound by causing vibrations in sets of metal reeds when air passes over them.', 'Concertina - A type of concert-sized accordion, offering larger size and a different configuration of bellows and buttons.', 'Harmonica - Another compact reed instrument closely related to the accordion in terms of design and functionality.', 'Klezmer - Jewish folk music traditionally played with instruments such as accordions or violins.', 'Brass band - Ensembles that commonly feature accordions among their lineup, especially for traditional and military marches.', 'Dixieland - A style of jazz that incorporates brass bands and often features the accordion in its arrangements.', 'Jazz - Accordions are sometimes used as a rhythm section instrument or solo performer within various styles of this genre.', 'Slide - An accordion technique where players slide their fingers across the keyboard to create smooth transitions between notes and chords.', "Compactness - A key attribute of accordions, allowing them to fit comfortably in a musician's hands and play portable performances.", 'Bellow system - The method by which air is manipulated within an accordion using bellows, creating sound through vibrating reeds.', 'Chromaticism - A musical technique frequently employed on the accordion to add expressive nuances and sharper pitch variations.', 'Pull-string system - An alternative mechanism found in some accordions that manipulates airflow instead of bellows, creating sound through reed vibrations.', 'Requinto - A type of Spanish guitar used to accompany folk music often played alongside an accordion ensemble.', 'Cajón - While not directly related to the accordion, this percussion instrument originating from Afro-Peruvian culture can complement accordion rhythms in certain musical settings.', 'Harmonization - The process of adding additional notes and chords on an accordion to enhance melodies or create harmonic structures within a piece.']

CLUE: Out of fashion, like ancient headgear
OUTPUT: ['Bonnet - A type of old-fashioned hat worn by women in past centuries.', 'Phrygian Cap - A soft cap with a projecting peak reminiscent of ancient Greece and Rome.', 'Turban - A distinctive headdress consisting of a cloth wound into shape around the head, traditionally associated with various cultures including Ancient Persia.', 'Beret - While still in fashion, it has roots in French military headgear from the 19th century.', 'Chaperon - A type of hat or hood characterized by a high crown and overlapping sides, often seen as old-fashioned.', 'Top Hat - Once a staple at formal events but now considered outdated for everyday wear.', 'Pileus Cap - A brimless cap with a cloth peak popular in ancient Greece and Rome.', 'Kippah - Although still worn by some, the traditional Jewish skullcap is not widely adopted globally as fashionable headgear.', 'Beanie - While commonly seen today, beanies have historical origins dating back to the late 19th century.', 'Cocked Hat - An old-fashioned type of hat with a forward brim, often associated with Victorian era fashion.', 'Bonnet Flat - A flattened version of traditional bonnets that were common in early modern Europe.', 'Kepi - A cap with a visor and flat crown, originally used by European military forces but now considered old-fashioned for civilian attire.', 'Tudor Cap - The distinctive pointed hat worn during the Tudor period (1485–1603) in England, rarely seen in modern fashion.', 'Shako - A tall cylindrical military cap with a visored top that fell out of favor after being replaced by other headgear styles.', 'Helm - An ancient type of helmet worn for protection but also used as ceremonial or decorative headwear in the past.', 'Knot-tying Cap - A simple, utilitarian cap featuring a knot on top; this style is rarely seen today and considered outdated.', 'Pileus Bandana Hat - An ancient cap with a cloth bandanna at the back, often associated with historical religious practices.', "Morion Helmet - A type of full-face helmets used by Moorish knights in Spain during medieval times; it's now considered old-fashioned.", 'Tressow - An ornate form of headgear worn by women from the 16th to the 17th century, characterized by elaborate featherwork and lace trims that are not commonly seen in modern fashion.', "Biretta - A square cap with three or four curved points traditionally worn by Roman Catholic priests; it's now used mainly for ceremonial occasions and is considered outdated for everyday wear."]

['Altar - A table or flat-topped block used as the focus for religious ritual or for worship, often considered a sacred place.', 'Cathedral - A large and important church building where religious services are held, typically regarded as holy ground.', 'Temple - A building dedicated to religious activities, especially one significant in public worship.', 'Shrine - A holy or sacred place dedicated to a specific deity, person, or event, often visited for devotion.', 'Chapel - A small, usually Christian, place of prayer and worship that is considered sacred by some believers.', 'Mosque - A Muslim house of worship where religious prayers are conducted, regarded as a sacred space.', 'Church - A building used for Christian religious activities such as congregational worship and ceremonies, often seen as holy ground.', 'Monastery - An institution in which monks live under religious vows, usually considered a sacred place of spiritual growth.', 'Sanctuary - A place that is regarded as holy or safe from harm; often used to describe a space for worship and refuge.', 'Holy well - A spring believed to have miraculous powers, often considered a sacred site by those who visit it for religious purposes.', 'Pilgrimage - A journey undertaken for religious reasons to a place of significance, such as a shrine or holy site.', 'Sanctification - The process of making something sacred, especially through consecration in religious rituals.', 'Reverence - Deep respect and honor given towards someone or something considered sacred.', 'Veneration - Adoration or deep respect shown towards a person, object, or concept held as holy.', 'Divine - Of or relating to God or other supernatural beings; often used to describe sacred concepts and objects.', 'Sacredness - The quality of being regarded with reverence, honor, or devotion due to its spiritual significance.', 'Ritualistic - Pertaining to rituals that involve actions performed as part of a religious or cultural ceremony in a sacred space.', 'Spirituality - A set of beliefs and practices related to the human spirit or soul; often associated with sacredness and divine connection.', 'Oracle - A person regarded as an intermediary between mortals and gods, capable of answering questions through supernatural means in a sacred space.', 'Worship - The act of showing reverence and adoration for a deity or divine being; often performed within a holy or sacred location.']

['Prototype - An early or preliminary version of something from which later versions are developed, especially in engineering and design fields.', 'Progenitor - A direct ancestor or one who is an originating source; often used to describe the first individual or species in a lineage.', 'Primordial - Existing at or from the beginning of time; ancient or earliest period.', 'Prehistoric - Relating to the distant past before written records were kept, also known as "antiquity."', 'Precursor - Something that comes before and indicates or signals the approach or existence of something else.', 'Prophet - A person regarded as an inspired teacher or proclaimer of the will of a deity; foresighted predictor in religious contexts, but also used more generally to indicate someone who predicts future events.', 'Genesis (Latin) - The origin or mode of formation of something', 'Progeny - Offspring; descendants in general, not necessarily direct lineage.', 'Primordial soup - A hypothetical mixture of chemicals present on Earth billions of years ago that could have led to the formation of life (based on the "primordial soup theory").', 'Ancestral - Pertaining to ancestors; derived from or related to past generations.', 'Archaic - Belonging to an earlier period in history, not current or modern.', 'Genesis (Greek: "γένεσις") - The origin or mode of formation of something; also the first book of the Bible, referring to creation and early mankind.', 'Progeny (Latin: "progenies") - Offspring; descendants in general, not necessarily direct lineage.', 'Primordial - Existing from or dating back to the beginning of time.', 'Prototype design (engineering) - An original model on which later versions are based; an early sample or model for testing a concept.', 'Precursor technology (tech industry) - Earlier, pioneering technologies that pave the way for more advanced developments in their respective fields.', 'Prophetic vision - A foresighted prediction of future events often seen as divine guidance or insight into potential outcomes.', 'Genesis narrative (Judaism and Christianity) - The story or account found within the first book of the Bible, which describes creation, early mankind, and the origins of various religious traditions.', 'Progenitor species (biology) - A group of organisms from which subsequent groups derive; ancestral species that contribute to current biodiversity.', 'Primordial matter (cosmology) - The basic substance or material thought to have existed before the formation of the universe as we know it today, often associated with theories on the Big Bang and cosmic inflation.']

['Stench - An intense, unpleasant smell often associated with decay or spoilage.', 'Foul odor - A disagreeable and offensive scent emanating from various sources such as waste materials or chemicals.', 'Pungency - The quality of being sharply strong-tasting or smelling, especially a spicy taste or odor.', 'Malodorous - Having an unpleasant or objectionable odor.', 'Nauseating stench - A repulsive and sickening smell that can cause discomfort or nausea.', "Skunky - Characterized by a strong, unpleasant smell reminiscent of the skunk's spray.", 'Rancid - Having an offensive, unpleasant smell often associated with spoiled food containing fat.', 'Corpulent - Although primarily describing someone who is overweight, it can also refer to a strong, sickly-smelling body odor in extreme cases.', 'Putrid - Extremely foul and decaying; often used to describe dead bodies or rotten organic matter.', 'Noxious - Harmful, especially in terms of causing physical discomfort through offensive smells.', 'Offensive odor - A disagreeable scent that can cause emotional distress or revulsion.', 'Pestiferous stench - An odor caused by pests such as rodents, insects, or decaying matter.', 'Squalid - Unhygienic and dirty; often associated with a foul smell emanating from unclean environments.', 'Obnoxious - Intolerably offensive, including in terms of strong and disagreeable odors.', 'Cloying sweetness - An overly sweet taste or scent that is overwhayering and unpleasant to some people.', 'Acrid - Harsh, bitter, and pungently sharp; can describe a burning smell as well as an offensive odor.', 'Exhalation - The act of breathing out which sometimes results in noticeable body odors or bad breath.', 'Lethal fumes - Toxic gases or vapors that can be deadly when inhaled; not specifically about smell, but they can also refer to overpoweringly offensive odors.', 'Putridity - The state of being rotten and emitting a decaying, repugnant odor.', 'Peculiar stench - An unusual or unfamiliar foul-smelling scent that can be difficult to describe accurately.']
